It is used to calibrate the TransRoad_LRS2008 route systems, including the End-to-End and Town-based LRSs.</purpose> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>20111231</caldate> </sngdate> Most of these are named streets in urban areas, which are mostly class 3. From the original road centerline data, any road with CLASS = 99 (unknown). </edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>95</edomv> <edomvd>Road class under special review, usually temporary</edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>96</edomv> <edomvd>Discontinued</edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>97</edomv> <edomvd>Not used (to avoid confusion with AOTCLASS = 97)</edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>98</edomv> <edomvd> Not considered a road based on local/regional review, but maintained in the data because it is on the VTrans town highway map </edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>99</edomv> <edomvd> Unknown class (assumed private, but not originally coded as private) Class 4 roads on the VTrans maps include provisional class 4 roads. These are legally class 3, but have a class 4 level of service. They are shown as class 4 because the VTrans does not provide state aid for them. </edomvd> </edom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>SCALE</attrlabl> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>ANGLE</attrlabl> ArcExplorer software.</techpreq> <availabl> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>20111231</caldate> <time>unknown</time> </sngdate> </timeinfo> </availabl> </distinfo> <metainfo> <metd>20111231</metd> <metc> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>VT Center for Geographic Information</cntorg> <cntper>GIS Database Administrator</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype> <address>58 South Main Street, Suite 2</address> <city>Waterbury</city> <state>VT</state> <postal>05676</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>802/882-3000</cntvoice> <cnttdd>None</cnttdd> <cntfax>802/882-3001</cntfax> </cntinfo> </metc> <metstdn>FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata</metstdn> <metstdv>FGDC-STD-001-1998</metstdv> <mettc>local time</mettc> <metac>None</metac> <metuc>None</metuc> <metsi> <metscs>N/A</metscs> <metsc>Unclassified</metsc> <metshd>No security considerations</metshd> </metsi> </metainfo> 2008 UPDATE: No documentation available from VTrans for this update.  2007 UPDATE: VTrans moved data into ArcSDE and worked on matching the intersecting road points to match the road centerline nodes.  Correction to the road alignments was performed to correct any issues and the route log points were subsequently moved.  VTrans ran a routine to identify missing and moved points and made the necessary corrections.  Some points may still require correction to match the roads, or the roads require proper alignment.  Road names coding - RDNAME was updated to match the new E911 format and many points were linked to their corresponding arcs in the TransRoad_RDS data layer.  2006 UPDATE: VTrans identified missing points and added these features.  Mileage values, road names, and other attribute data were updated as necessary.  2005 UPDATE: VTrans provided VCGI with the latest copy of RTLOGPTS for use during the development of LRS2005.  VCGI identified and corrected numerous errors.  Updates also included A: Verified that there was a point at least every two miles tagged as a calibration point for every TWN/ETE route (USEFORCAL = Y within RTLOGPTS2005).  Tagged additional RTLOGPTS2005 points as needed.  If a point was not available for tagging (USEFORCAL = Y), VCGI wrote the FROM_MM/TO_MM and Route ID (ETE_LR/TWN_LR) for the given section to a "linear event table".  VTrans provided VCGI a file which included LRS and milemarker information for bridges on interstate, US, and state highways.  VCGI wrote a python script which snagged points from VTrans bridge data which were in the identified areas which did not meet the 2 mile specification.  All of these procedures added over 2000 points to the coverage.  KNOWN PROBLEMS (2005 UPDATE): 1.The following points in RTLOGPTS2005 have inconsistent mileages with other points in the same location. a.POINTID = 15808, 12439, 5920, 9426, 11889, 11934, 12993 2.S06041121 mileages are wrong. 3.Mileages issues at the start of S01770910.  It looks like there are some realignment issues. 4.POINTID 21017 has a TWN_MM error.  2004 UPDATE: VTrans provided VCGI with the latest copy of RTLOGPTS for use during the development of LRS2004.  VCGI identified and corrected numerous errors.  VCGI added two attributes to the PAT called UPDACT (update action) and UPDCOMMENTS.  These two attributes document the updates made by VCGI.  Additional edits were made by VTrans, however, these have not been documented.  HISTORICAL: The information below describes the creation of RTLOGPTS2002, which was the original release of RTLOGPTS.  RTLOGPTS2002 was developed through a three phase data integration and QA/QC process (managed by VCGI). PHASE 1 -  RTLOGPTS points were derived from two primary sources; RDS\\CPTS2000 (existing calibration point coverage) and a VTran's Route Log intersection database (event table - IntersectingRoads.mdb provided by Johnathan Croft 2005 - VTrans).  The route log event table was converted into a point coverage using dynamic segmentation (applied against RDS\\LRS2000).  A Visual Basic program (which called an AML) was used to combine these two coverages into a single data layer.  The program looked for points in the route log intersection coverage (RTLOGPTS) which matched points in the calibration coverage (CPTS2000).  Those that were within 15 meters, had the same LR_TWN value, and had the same LRTWN_MI value (within a tolerance of 0.01 miles) were tagged as matches.  Some of the key CPTS2000 attributes were then carried into the RTLOGPTS coverage.  The remaining points in CPTS2000 which did not match any of the points in RTLOGPTS were then put to RTLOGPTS.  VCGI checked to make sure that every calibration point originally present in CPTS2000 had a representation in the RTLOGPTS coverage.  There was a one to one match.  All of the points in RTLOGPTS (the combined coverage) were snapped to RDS\\RDSALL (2002 release) nodes within 20 meters.  Mileages were derived from VTrans Route Logs and other sources (refer to MILE_SRC). PHASE 2 -  This phase included moving all intersection points to match the "true" intersection location based on 5K VT digital orthophotography. This was done for all route log intersection points.  STATION numbers were also verified against hardcopy VTrans Route Logs.  In a few cases STATION numbers had to be corrected.  In these cases the LRTWN_MI (MILEAGE) value was also updated.  VCGI verified that FIPS6, CTCODE, and TOWNNAME values were consistent.  Spatial consistency of FIPS6 with TBHASH was also checked, but there are many cases in which TBHASH isn't very accurate.  In these cases VCGI used the VTrans Route Logs to determine the correct FIPS6.  Points have been flagged to indicate whether they they should be used for calibration of VTrans' LRS coverage (USEFORCAL) or for VTrans' Route Log system (USEFORRTLG).  There are cases in which points can be used for both.  Also flagged route log intersections which did not match (not within 5 meters) the master RDSALL road centerline intersection nodes.  Adjusted mileages for South and West bound sections of divided highways which had been using DMI based mileages to match North and East bound lanes (I089-S,I091-S,I093-S,U004-W).  RDFLNAME values were verified against E911\\RDS data using automated procedures.  However, only 440 points of out of 6404 route log intersection stations could be verified.  These were assigned the E911\\RDS road name and RDNAME value.  All other RDFLNAME values need to be manually verified (QC_FLAG = 2), which is beyond the scope of the "Calibration and Route Log Points Data Development Project" between VTrans and VCGI.  RTNAME values were verified against the "master" RDS\\RDSALL (RDSnnnnn) coverage (2005 release).  VCGI was able to verify 3745 points ouf of 6404 route log intersection stations.  All other RTNAME values need to be manually verified (QC_FLAG = 1), which is beyond the scope of the project.  If both RTNAME and RDFLNAME need to be manually verified they have been flagged with QC_FLAG = 3. PHASE 3 - The final phase included two primary tasks; 1) Refreshing of ETE_LR and ETE_MM by porting TWN_LR and TWN_MM, and 2) final attribute consistency checking.  First VCGI recalced all TWN_MM = TWN_ST / 5280.  VCGI refreshed ETE_LR and ETE_MM values by dumping the RTLOGPTS2002.PAT to a dBase IV file then using a FoxPro program (developed by Jim Mossman VTrans 1999) to "port" TWN_MM values to ETE_MM.  The refreshed values were then loaded back into the RTLOGPTS20112005.PAT using a table join.  VCGI ran a final check to make sure FIPS6, CTCODE, and TOWNNAME values were consistent.  VCGI also verified that all points tagged as calibration points (USEFORCAL = Y) had start/end mileages matching MRDTABLE2005.DBF (both ETE and TWN). <posacc> <horizpa> <horizpar> There has been substantial work correcting the road centerlines to match the orthophotography.  Some of the intersections may not fully match the node locations in the RDS data layer.  In 2005, VCGI had snapped all points to match intersections in the master road centerline coverage (RDS\\RDSALL).  All route log intersection points (USEFORRTLOG = Y) were verified against VT's 5K digital orthos.  Those points not within 5 meters of the road centerline intersection were flagged with FIXRDS = Y (meaning these road intersections in the master RDS\\RDSALL data need to be verified).  NOTE:  VTrans personnel may conclude that some of these are erroneous.  Since the data has been moved into ArcSDE, and significant work has taken place on the road centerlines, some of the intersections may not match the roads.  Much effort has gone into correcting the intersecting road and calibration points, but the data has not been universally reviewed.  Review has occurred on a town by town basis to date. </horizpar> </horizpa> <vertacc></vertacc> </posacc> <lineage> <srcinfo> <srccite> <citeinfo> <origin>VTrans</origin> <pubdate>20111231</pubdate> <pubtime>Unknown</pubtime> <title>VTrans 2008 Route Log intersection and LRS calibration point layer (RTLOGPTS2011)</title> <geoform>database</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Montpelier, VT</pubplace> <publish>VTrans</publish> </pubinfo> </citeinfo> </srccite> <srcscale>NA</srcscale> <typesrc>paper</typesrc> <srctime> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>20111231</caldate> <time>unknown</time> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <srccurr>publication date</srccurr> </srctime> <srccitea>TransRoad_RTLOGPTS2011</srccitea> <srccontr>VTrans</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>Completed RTLOGPTS2002 data layer. Tagged additional RTLOGPTS2005 points as needed.  If a point was not available for tagging (USEFORCAL = Y), VCGI wrote the FROM_MM/TO_MM and Route ID (ETE_LR/TWN_LR) for the given section to a "linear event table".  VTrans provided VCGI a file which included LRS and milemarker information for bridges on interstate, US, and state highways.  VCGI wrote a python script which snagged points from VTrans bridge data which were in the identified areas which did not meet the 2 mile specification.
